{{stack begin}} {{Taxobox | image = Phallus_hadriani.jpg | image_caption = | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Phallales]] | familia = [[Phallaceae]] | genus = ''[[Phallus (genus)|Phallus]]'' | species = '''''P. hadriani''''' | binomial = ''Phallus hadriani'' | binomial_authority = [[Étienne Pierre Ventenat|Vent.]] | synonyms_ref = | synonyms = 1817 ''Hymenophallus hadriani'' (Vent.) [[Christian Gottfried Daniel Nees von Esenbeck|Nees]]
1836 ''Phallus iosmus'' [[Miles Joseph Berkeley|Berk.]]
1873 ''Phallus imperialis'' [[Stephan V.M. Schulzer von Müggenburg|Schulzer]]
''Ithyphallus impudicus'' var. ''imperialis'' (Schulzer) [[Giovanni Batista De Toni|De Toni]]
''Ithyphallus impudicus'' var. ''iosmos'' (Berk.) De Toni }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Phallus hadriani'' | capShape = conical | hymeniumType = gleba | ecologicalType=saprotrophic | sporePrintColor=olive | howEdible=edible | howEdible2=caution }} {{stack end}} '''''Phallus hadriani''''', commonly known as the '''dune stinkhorn''', is a species of [[fungus]] in the [[Phallaceae]] (stinkhorn) family. It is a widely distributed species, and is native to Asia, Europe, and North America. In Australia, it is probably an [[introduced species]]. The [[stipe (mycology)|stalk]] of the [[basidiocarp|fruit body]] reaches up to {{convert|20|cm|in|abbr=on}} tall by {{convert|4|cm|in|abbr=on}} thick, and is spongy, fragile, and hollow. At the top of the stem is a ridged and pitted, thimble-like cap over which is spread olive-colored [[spore]] slime ([[gleba]]). Shortly after emerging, the gleba liquefies and releases a fetid odor that attracts insects, which help disperse the spores. Said to be [[edible mushroom|edible]] in its immature egg-like stage, it typically grows in public lawns, yards and gardens, usually in sandy soils. ''Phallus hadriani'' may be distinguished from the similar ''[[Phallus impudicus|P. impudicus]]'' (the common stinkhorn) by the presence of a pink or violet-colored [[volva (mycology)|volva]] at the base of the stem, and by differences in odor. ==Taxonomy== The species was first [[species description|described scientifically]] by the French botanist [[Étienne Pierre Ventenat]] in 1798, and [[sanctioned name|sanctioned]] by [[Christiaan Hendrik Persoon]] under that name in his 1801 ''Synopsis Methodica Fungorum''. [[Christian Gottfried Daniel Nees von Esenbeck]] called the species ''Hymenophallus hadriani'' in 1817; this name is a [[synonym (biology)|synonym]]. According to the taxonomical database [[Index Fungorum]], additional synonyms include: ''Phallus iosmus'', named by [[Miles Joseph Berkeley|Berkeley]] in 1836; ''Phallus imperialis'', [[Stephan V.M. Schulzer von Müggenburg|Schulzer]], 1873; ''Ithyphallus impudicus'' var. ''imperialis'' and ''Ithyphallus impudicus'' var. ''iosmos'', [[Giovanni Batista De Toni|De Toni]], date unknown. The [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] ''hadriani'' is named after the Dutch botanist [[Hadrianus Junius]] (1512–1575), who wrote a pamphlet on stinkhorn mushrooms in 1564 (''Phalli, ex fungorum genere, in Hollandiae''). ==Description== [[File:Phallus hadriani.JPG|thumb|left|The pink volva is what remains of the tough outer covering of the immature egg.]] The immature fruiting bodies of ''P. hadriani'' in the egg stage have dimensions of {{convert|4|to|6|cm|in|abbr=on}} by {{convert|3|to|4|cm|in|abbr=on}}, and are colored rosy-pink to violet. They typically have [[rhizomorphs]] (aggregations of [[mycelium]] that resemble plant roots) at the base. The eggs are enclosed in a tough covering and a gelatinous layer that breaks down as the stinkhorn emerges. Mature fruiting bodies, which may be {{convert|10|to|20|cm|in|abbr=on}} tall by {{convert|3|to|4|cm|in|abbr=on}} thick, have a white- or cream-colored hollow [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] that is spongy and honeycombed. The head is [[wikt:reticulate|reticulate]], ridged and pitted, and covered with olive green [[gleba]]l mass. The [[volva (mycology)|volva]] is cuplike, and typically retains its pink color although it may turn brownish with age. Fruit bodies are short-lived, typically lasting only one or two days. Although the odor of ''P. hadriani'' has been described by some authors as faint and pleasant or like [[Viola odorata|violets]], others describe the smell as [[wikt:fetid|fetid]] or putrid. The gleba is known to attract insects, including flies, bees, and beetles, some of which consume the spore-containing slime. It is thought that long-distance spore dispersal is facilitated by these insects, who may deposit in their feces intact spores that survive the passage through the digestive tract. The [[spore]]s are cylindrical, smooth, and [[hyaline]] (translucent), with dimensions of 3–4 by 1–2 [[micrometre|µm]]. The [[basidia]] (spore-bearing cells) are cylindrical, with dimensions of 20–25 by 3–4 µm. They have eight [[sterigmata]] (slender extensions that attach to the spores), as well as a clamp at their base. ===Edibility=== [[File:Phallus hadriani eggs.jpg|thumb|right|A cross-section of the immature, edible egg-form]] Like many other stinkhorns, this species is thought to be [[edible mushroom|edible]] when in its egg form. Central Europeans and the Chinese consider the eggs a delicacy. Regarding the edibility of mature specimens, one author commented on the genus in general, "No one with his sense of smell developed would think of eating the members of this group." ===Similar species=== ''[[Phallus impudicus]]'' has the same overall appearance as ''P. hadriani'', but is distinguished by its white volva. Another similar stinkhorn, ''[[Phallus ravenelii|P. ravenelii]]'' has a smooth, not reticulate head. ==Habitat and distribution== ''Phallus hadriani'' is known to be in [[Australia]] (where it is thought to be an [[introduced species]] imported on [[Woodchipping|woodchip]] mulch used in gardening and landscaping), [[North America]], [[Europe]] (including Denmark, Ireland, Latvia, The Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Slovakia, Sweden, Ukraine, and Wales) Turkey ([[Iğdır Province]]), [[Japan]], and China ([[Jilin Province]]). ''Phallus hadriani'' is a [[saprobic]] species, and thus obtains nutrients by decomposing organic matter. In North America, it is commonly associated with tree stumps, or roots of stumps that are decomposing in the ground. In [[Great Britain]], its distribution is more or less restricted to coastal [[dune]]s, while in Poland, it has been noted to avoid humid and [[humic acid|humic]] forest soils, and live in symbiosis with [[xerophilous]] grasses and the black locust tree, ''[[Robinia pseudoacacia]]''. The mushroom is one of three species [[protected species|protected]] by the [[Regional Red List|Red Data Book]] of Latvia. {{Clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em|refs= {{cite book |author=Arora D. |title=All that the Rain Promises and More: a Hip Pocket Guide to Western Mushrooms |publisher=Ten Speed Press |location=Berkeley, CA |year=1991 |page=241 |isbn=0-89815-388-3 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=87ct90d4B9gC&lpg=PA241&dq=phallus%20hadriani&pg=PA241#v=onepage&q=phallus%20hadriani&f=false |accessdate=2010-10-12}} {{cite book |title=Mushrooms of the Southeastern United States |vauthors=Bessette AE, Roody WC, Bessette AR |year=2007 |publisher=[[Syracuse University Press]] |location=Syracuse, NY |isbn=978-0-8156-3112-5 |page=277 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IB1Gv3jZMmAC&lpg=PA277&dq=phallus%20hadriani&pg=PA277#v=onepage&q=phallus%20hadriani&f=false |accessdate=2010-10-12}} {{cite journal |vauthors=Brouwer E, Braat M, van Hoek B, Noteboom R, Oplaat C, de Peijper R, Smits M, Klok P |year=2009 |title=WAD'N GEZWAM!
